clusters.title: Hundreds of Everest hikers reach safety after snowstorm in Tibetan valley
clusters.neutral_headline: Hundreds of Everest Hikers Rescued After Blizzard

items.title: Hundreds of Everest hikers reach safety after snowstorm in Tibetan valley
items.standfirst: Those rescued included guides, yak herders and trekkers, who were trapped in a heavy snowstorm that began on Friday.
items.content: Those rescued included guides, yak herders and trekkers, who were trapped in a heavy snowstorm that began on Friday.

items.title: Hundreds of hikers rescued from Mount Everest after severe snowstorm
items.standfirst: About 900 hikers, guides and other staff who were stranded by a weekend snowstorm on the Chinese side of Mount Everest have reached safety, state media said late Tuesday.
items.content: About 900 hikers, guides and other staff who were stranded by a weekend snowstorm on the Chinese side of Mount Everest have reached safety, state media said late Tuesday.(Image credit: Lingsuiye/AP)

items.title: 🏔️ Hundreds of trekkers escape from blizzard-struck Everest in Tibet
items.standfirst: ❄️ Hundreds of trekkers stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest in Tibet have been guided to safety by rescuers, Chinese state media reported, as unusually heavy snow and rainfall pummelled the Himalayas. 🇨🇳 Outdoor enthusiasts have flocked to China's rugged interior since an eight-day holiday began on October 1, but a sudden blizzard over the weekend caught off guard hundreds of hikers hoping to catch a glimpse of Everest's Kangshung face. ⛑️ Some 350 trekkers have reached the small town of Qudang, while more than 200 trekkers still stranded in freezing temperatures are expected to be evacuated by Tuesday.
items.content: ❄️ Hundreds of trekkers stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest in Tibet have been guided to safety by rescuers, Chinese state media reported, as unusually heavy snow and rainfall pummelled the Himalayas. 🇨🇳 Outdoor enthusiasts have flocked to China's rugged interior since an eight-day holiday began on October 1, but a sudden blizzard over the weekend caught off guard hundreds of hikers hoping to catch a glimpse of Everest's Kangshung face. ⛑️ Some 350 trekkers have reached the small town of Qudang, while more than 200 trekkers still stranded in freezing temperatures are expected to be evacuated by Tuesday.

items.title: Stranded Mount Everest hikers being evacuated
items.standfirst: More than 200 people left stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest are being evacuated, Reuters news agency reports.
items.content: More than 200 people left stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest are being evacuated, Reuters news agency reports.

items.title: 'I was lucky to get out': Everest hikers battle hypothermia as blizzard rescue continues
items.standfirst: At least one hiker has died and hundreds are still stranded near the mountain's eastern face.
items.content: At least one hiker has died and hundreds are still stranded near the mountain's eastern face.

items.title: More than 200 hikers still stranded as blizzard hits Mount Everest
items.standfirst: Chinese rescuers were on Monday rushing to evacuate hundreds of hikers stranded on the eastern slope of the world's highest mountain, Mount Everest, after heavy snowfall blanketed campsites over the weekend
items.content: Chinese rescuers were on Monday rushing to evacuate hundreds of hikers stranded on the eastern slope of the world's highest mountain, Mount Everest, after heavy snowfall blanketed campsites over the weekend

items.title: Mount Everest hikers describe ‘extreme’ conditions as huge rescue effort continues
items.standfirst: At least 200 people still stranded after unseasonally heavy snowfall during China’s Golden Week holidayTrekkers have described facing “extreme” conditions after an unseasonable snowstorm during one of China’s busiest holiday weekends stranded hundreds of people on Mount Everest, prompting a massive rescue effort.Chinese authorities said about 350 people had made their way down but at least 200 remained stranded at the Everest Scenic Area, to the east of the mountain, on the Tibetan side of the border. Continue reading...
items.content: At least 200 people still stranded after unseasonally heavy snowfall during China’s Golden Week holidayTrekkers have described facing “extreme” conditions after an unseasonable snowstorm during one of China’s busiest holiday weekends stranded hundreds of people on Mount Everest, prompting a massive rescue effort.Chinese authorities said about 350 people had made their way down but at least 200 remained stranded at the Everest Scenic Area, to the east of the mountain, on the Tibetan side of the border. Continue reading...

items.title: Watch: Race to reach hikers stranded by Mount Everest blizzard
items.standfirst: Chinese state media reports say around 350 people have been rescued and efforts are under way to reach more than 200 others.
items.content: Chinese state media reports say around 350 people have been rescued and efforts are under way to reach more than 200 others.

Rescuers guided hundreds of trekkers to safety near the eastern face of Mount Everest in Tibet.

At least one hiker died, and hundreds are still stranded near the mountain's eastern face.

items.standfirst: President Emmanuel Macron under pressure as parliamentary paralysis persists.
items.content: President Emmanuel Macron under pressure as parliamentary paralysis persists.

items.title: Time may be running out for master of clocks Macron: What next for France?
items.standfirst: After eight years in office, Emmanuel Macron's position as president is coming under increasing pressure as France's political crisis escalates.
items.content: After eight years in office, Emmanuel Macron's position as president is coming under increasing pressure as France's political crisis escalates.

items.title: Former PM and Macron ally Édouard Philippe joins calls for president's resignation
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron's first and longest-serving prime minister, Édouard Philippe, urged him to resign on Monday, suggesting that polls should be held early once a budget is passed. The appeal came a day after Sébastien Lecornu, France’s latest prime minister, resigned less than a month after being appointed, deepening the political crisis.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron's first and longest-serving prime minister, Édouard Philippe, urged him to resign on Monday, suggesting that polls should be held early once a budget is passed. The appeal came a day after Sébastien Lecornu, France’s latest prime minister, resigned less than a month after being appointed, deepening the political crisis.

items.title: Macron under pressure to call snap parliamentary elections or resign
items.standfirst: French president’s former allies join opponents in demanding he act to end a spiralling political crisisFrance’s president, Emmanuel Macron, is under intense pressure to call snap parliamentary elections or resign as former allies join his opponents in demanding he act to end a spiralling political crisis in the EU’s second biggest economy.Macron’s first prime minister on Tuesday urged the president to step down amid mounting frustration even within the president’s own camp over one of the worst spells of political chaos in France since the foundation of its Fifth Republic in 1958. Continue reading...
items.content: French president’s former allies join opponents in demanding he act to end a spiralling political crisisFrance’s president, Emmanuel Macron, is under intense pressure to call snap parliamentary elections or resign as former allies join his opponents in demanding he act to end a spiralling political crisis in the EU’s second biggest economy.Macron’s first prime minister on Tuesday urged the president to step down amid mounting frustration even within the president’s own camp over one of the worst spells of political chaos in France since the foundation of its Fifth Republic in 1958. Continue reading...

clusters.title: White House memo says federal workers may not get automatic backpay: Report
clusters.neutral_headline: White House Suggests Back Pay Unlikely for Some Federal Workers

items.title: White House memo says federal workers may not get automatic backpay: Report
items.standfirst: The memo is seen as a pressure tactic on Democrats as the US government shutdown heads into its eighth day.
items.content: The memo is seen as a pressure tactic on Democrats as the US government shutdown heads into its eighth day.

items.title: Draft White House memo suggests furloughed government workers are not guaranteed pay
items.standfirst: President Trump was questioned on Tuesday about whether federal workers will receive back pay for salaries lost due to the government shutdown. The questions came after a draft White House memo suggested furloughed federal workers and employees working without pay are not guaranteed compensation. CBS News White House reporter Aaron Navarro has more.
items.content: President Trump was questioned on Tuesday about whether federal workers will receive back pay for salaries lost due to the government shutdown. The questions came after a draft White House memo suggested furloughed federal workers and employees working without pay are not guaranteed compensation. CBS News White House reporter Aaron Navarro has more.

items.title: White House suggests some federal workers may not get back pay after shutdown
items.standfirst: With the shutdown about to enter its second week, Trump says some furloughed workers "don't deserve to be taken care of".
items.content: With the shutdown about to enter its second week, Trump says some furloughed workers "don't deserve to be taken care of".

items.title: White House says furloughed federal workers not entitled to back pay amid shutdown
items.standfirst: OMB argues an amendment to a 2019 act would not guarantee furloughed workers post-shutdown payThe White House’s office of management and budget (OMB) is arguing that federal workers who are furloughed amid the ongoing government shutdown are not entitled to back pay.In a draft memo first obtained by Axios, OMB argued that an amendment to the Government Employee Fair Treatment Act (GEFTA) of 2019 would not guarantee furloughed workers back pay and that said funds must be set aside by Congress. Continue reading...
items.content: OMB argues an amendment to a 2019 act would not guarantee furloughed workers post-shutdown payThe White House’s office of management and budget (OMB) is arguing that federal workers who are furloughed amid the ongoing government shutdown are not entitled to back pay.In a draft memo first obtained by Axios, OMB argued that an amendment to the Government Employee Fair Treatment Act (GEFTA) of 2019 would not guarantee furloughed workers back pay and that said funds must be set aside by Congress. Continue reading...

items.title: White House floats no back pay for some furloughed federal workers despite 2019 law
items.standfirst: A new draft White House memo suggests a 2019 law signed by President Trump that guarantees that federal employees get paid after a shutdown ends would not apply to furloughed workers.
items.content: A new draft White House memo suggests a 2019 law signed by President Trump that guarantees that federal employees get paid after a shutdown ends would not apply to furloughed workers.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

ai_summary: A White House memo suggests furloughed federal workers may not receive back pay.
The memo is seen as a pressure tactic during the ongoing government shutdown.
The White House argues a 2019 act does not guarantee back pay for furloughed workers.
The draft memo suggests a 2019 law may not apply to furloughed workers.
President Trump was questioned about back pay for federal workers.

items.title: Live: Trump says 'real chance' to end Gaza war as Israel marks attacks anniversary
items.standfirst: Qatar's prime minister and Turkish delegates will join Hamas and Israeli negotiators in Egypt on Wednesday for a third day of talks aimed at ending the Gaza war. Indirect negotiations between Israel and Hamas are being held at the Red Sea resort town of Sharm El-Sheikh, based on a 20-point plan proposed by US President Donald Trump last month. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.
items.content: Qatar's prime minister and Turkish delegates will join Hamas and Israeli negotiators in Egypt on Wednesday for a third day of talks aimed at ending the Gaza war. Indirect negotiations between Israel and Hamas are being held at the Red Sea resort town of Sharm El-Sheikh, based on a 20-point plan proposed by US President Donald Trump last month. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.title: US delegation led by Steve Witkoff due to arrive in Egypt for Gaza talks
items.standfirst: White House says it is important ‘that we get this done quickly’ as indirect talks restart in Sharm el-SheikhA US delegation led by envoy Steve Witkoff is expected to join talks in Egypt on Wednesday to reinforce President Donald Trump’s involvement in the newly restarted negotiations between Hamas and Israel aimed at ending the war in Gaza.The indirect talks at Sharm el-Sheikh, the Egyptian resort city on the Red Sea, entered their second day on the second anniversary of the Hamas surprise attack into Israel that triggered the bloody conflict. Continue reading...

items.title: Thirty Bob Ross paintings to be sold at auction to help fund public TV stations
items.standfirst: Money will aid with licensing fees and ensure artist’s ‘legacy continues to support’ medium that made him popularThirty paintings created by the bushy-haired, soft-spoken Bob Ross will soon be up for auction to defray the costs of programming for small and rural public television stations suffering under cuts in federal funding.Ross, a public television stalwart in the 1980s and 90s, “dedicated his life to making art accessible to everyone”, said Joan Kowalski, president of Bob Ross Inc. “This auction ensures his legacy continues to support the very medium that brought his joy and creativity into American homes for decades.” Continue reading...
items.content: Money will aid with licensing fees and ensure artist’s ‘legacy continues to support’ medium that made him popularThirty paintings created by the bushy-haired, soft-spoken Bob Ross will soon be up for auction to defray the costs of programming for small and rural public television stations suffering under cuts in federal funding.Ross, a public television stalwart in the 1980s and 90s, “dedicated his life to making art accessible to everyone”, said Joan Kowalski, president of Bob Ross Inc. “This auction ensures his legacy continues to support the very medium that brought his joy and creativity into American homes for decades.” Continue reading...

items.title: Bob Ross paintings to be auctioned to raise money for public TV after cuts
items.standfirst: Thirty paintings by Bob Ross are set to be auctioned to support public television stations after federal funding cuts.
items.content: Thirty paintings by Bob Ross are set to be auctioned to support public television stations after federal funding cuts.

items.title: Burkina Faso's military junta arrests European humanitarian NGO workers for 'spying'
items.standfirst: Burkina Faso's military government said it had arrested eight members of a Hague-based humanitarian NGO on Tuesday, accusing them of collecting and sharing sensitive information detrimental to the African country's security. Those arrested included a Frenchman, a French-Senegalese woman, a Czech man, a Malian and four Burkinabe nationals.
